Situation1: A passenger who booked through the app is waiting and urgently pressing for a quicker arrival.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock, my hands gripping the steering wheel a little tighter. The app pinged again—my passenger, impatient, sent another message: “Please hurry, I really need to get there on time.” As a taxi driver, I knew my duty was to provide reliable, timely service. My rating depended on it, and so did my income. But my phone buzzed with another notification, this one from Sister Maria: “Please come, the healing service is starting soon. Sister Agnes needs all our prayers.” The service was unscheduled, called for the sake of a beloved, ailing member of our community. As a nun, I was expected to be present, to offer comfort and faith, especially in moments like this. My heart pounded with the weight of both worlds—one demanding my presence behind the wheel, the other at the altar. I stared at the intersection ahead, torn between the urgent needs of a stranger and the sacred call of my sisters, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
